channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Says New ‘Invincible’ Missile Can Pierce U.S. and European Defenses
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin offered Russians a rosy picture of future prosperity and military might in his annual speech, delivered on Thursday in Moscow.
item.description: Russians had wondered before Mr. Putin’s speech what he planned for his last term, and they got an answer: Russia will be a superpower again.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: The Mystery Man Who Runs Italy’s ‘Five Star’ From the Shadows
item.media:description: Davide Casaleggio, the son of the Five Star Movement’s co-founder, Gianroberto Casaleggio, has no official role in the party. But critics say he controls it from behind the scenes.
item.description: Davide Casaleggio, a media-shy internet entrepreneur, is the Wizard of Oz-like figure behind the curtain of the country’s leading party before Sunday’s elections.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Heaviest Snow in Decades Batters U.K., Ireland and the Continent
item.media:description: Lake Pecs, in central Hungary, froze over.
item.description: A rare Siberian chill is hitting Europe with unusually cold, snowy and windy conditions. Britain warned of a “risk to life,” and the country faces a natural gas shortage.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Pristina Journal: Not the Worst Hotel in the World, Perhaps, but ‘the World Is Very Big’
item.media:description: The Grand Hotel in Pristina, Kosovo.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: With 500 rooms, one guest, pigeons on the top floors and many cockroaches, the Grand Hotel in Kosovo reflects the travails of a new nation.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Carles Puigdemont, Catalan Leader, Steps Aside
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont at a news conference in Brussels in December. He has given up his campaign to be reappointed as Catalonia’s president.
item.description: The leader of the main separatist alliance in Catalonia, Carles Puigdemont, has given up his campaign to be reappointed as the region’s president.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Mexico to Quit Amid Tense Relations Under Trump
item.media:description: Roberta S. Jacobson, center, the United States ambassador to Mexico, during a ceremony last month to break ground for the new American Embassy in Mexico City.
item.description: Roberta S. Jacobson is one of the most experienced Latin America experts in the State Department, having spent most of her 31-year tenure focused on the region.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Why This Tech Executive Says Her Plan to Disrupt Education Is Different
item.media:description: Students at Lumineer Academy in Williamstown, Australia. The school uses an alternative learning model based on technology businesses.
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.description: Susan Wu, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, has opened a school in Australia.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Prince William Will Go to Israel, in First Official Visit by a British Royal
item.media:description: Prince William, second in line to the British throne, will visit Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian territories in the occupied West Bank this summer.
item.description: Nearly 70 years after the British Mandate ended Prince William will make an official visit to the area, ending what many Israelis saw as a royal snub.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: News Analysis: Pakistan’s Shields Suddenly Step Aside, Placing It on Terrorism Listing
item.media:description: Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the group suspected of being behind the deadly 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India, in Lahore, Pakistan, after a court ordered his release from house arrest. Pakistan is accused of not doing enough to stop groups that sponsor terrorism.
item.description: The acceptance by China and Saudi Arabia of the U.S. effort to list Pakistan as too lax on terrorism financing is prompting worry, and debate, in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Tariffs, Delta, Putin: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Poland and Israel in Tense Talks Over Law Likened to Holocaust Denial
item.media:description: Visitors wearing Israeli flags at the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial last month.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: The Polish law makes it a crime to blame “the Polish nation” for the Holocaust and other Nazi crimes.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and JOANNA BERENDT
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In Vatican Magazine Exposé, Nuns Reveal Their Economic Exploitation
item.media:description: Nuns at a Mass celebrated by Pope Francis with members of different religious orders in St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican last month.
item.description: Sisters are often relegated to unsung, and underpaid, roles in a male-centric church that does not recognize their talents or capabilities, according to nuns interviewed by a women’s magazine.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Putin Vows to Lift Russia’s Struggling Middle Class
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s speech on the state of the nation resonated as an acknowledgement that international sanctions continue to hurt ordinary Russians.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin used his annual address to lay out a plan to reduce poverty and revive middle class fortunes.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Confined on His Last Trip to Saudi Arabia, Lebanon’s Leader Returns on Better Terms
item.media:description: In a picture provided by the Saudi Royal Palace, King Salman, right, received Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, on Wednesday.
item.description: The Saudi news media showed Prime Minister Saad Hariri smiling and conferring with King Salman. There was no mention of the unpleasantness of the previous visit.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: South Korea Tells U.S. It Will Send Envoy to North Korea
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea notified President Trump on Thursday that his government would send an envoy to North Korea to help arrange talks between the North and the United States.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in informed President Trump that South Korea would send a special envoy to the North to help arrange talks with Washington.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Facebook to End News Feed Experiment in 6 Countries That Magnified Fake News
item.media:description: A booth at Facebook’s annual F8 developer conference in San Jose, Calif. The social network is stopping the experiment known as Explore, which separates news publishers from its main site.
item.description: The social network is ending Explore, an experiment in countries like Bolivia and Cambodia, where it had separated news and other publishers from its main site.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: Q Is for Queuing: Minting British Traditions With New 10-Pence Coins
item.media:description: The Royal Mint in Britain will release a new set of 10 pence coins with themes surrounding British traditions and icons this month.
item.description: Tea, an English breakfast and ice cream, along with icons from the obscure to the most famous, appear on the new coins designed for collectors and the public.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Germany Says Hackers Infiltrated Main Government Network
item.media:description: Hackers penetrated a German government system that is used by the chancellor’s office, ministries and the Parliament, above.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Officials said the attack was narrowly targeted, but they would not comment on reports of Russian involvement.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: China Detains Relatives of Radio Free Asia Reporters
item.media:description: Shohret Hoshur is one of at least four reporters whose family members are being held or whose whereabouts are unknown.
item.description: The journalists, U.S. citizens or permanent residents, have reported on China’s crackdown on the Uighur ethnic group in the Xinjiang region.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rites of Passage: Hi Hi Good Morning Hi I Love You It’s Me
item.media:description: Illustration by Tracy Ma/The New York Times
item.description: WhatsApp connects families around the world in amazing ways, and also is a complete nightmare.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Trilobites: They’re Hosting Parasitic Worms in Their Bodies to Help Treat a Neglected Disease
item.media:description: Schistosoma mansoni parasites, the cause of the disease bilharzia, or schistosomiasis. The brown worm is an adult male and the green one is female.
item.description: 17 healthy volunteers were paid to help prove a method of testing vaccines for schistosomiasis, which can be lethal, but some researchers are conflicted about the trial.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY

item.title: 5 Places: Five Places to Go in Nashville
item.media:description: Andrew Hannigan prepares cocktails at Bastion bar and restaurant in Nashville's Wedgewood-Houston neighborhood.
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.description: Nashville’s Wedgewood-Houston neighborhood was long a run-down part of town. After creative types moved into the area, trendy restaurants, galleries, distilleries and other business have followed.
item.dc:creator: SHIVANI VORA

item.title: China’s Censors Ban Winnie the Pooh and the Letter ‘N’ After Xi’s Power Grab
item.description: Censors swung into action after Mr. Xi’s bid to become leader for life resurrected memories of Mao’s personality cult and the feverish emotions that it created.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Egypt Is Using Banned U.S.-Made Cluster Munitions in Sinai, Rights Group Says
item.media:description: Images from Egypt’s Defense Ministry are said to show Egyptian soldiers on a counterterrorism mission in the Sinai Peninsula. Amnesty International has accused Egypt of using outlawed cluster bombs in its Sinai campaign.
item.description: The use of such weapons would violate an international treaty and possibly American laws regarding recipients of American military aid.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How China’s Media Sold Xi Jinping’s Power Grab
item.description: Soon after China’s Communist Party announced a plan to end presidential term limits, its censors and propaganda machine kicked into high gear. Here’s how it unfolded.

item.title: Exxon Mobil Scraps a Russian Deal, Stymied by Sanctions
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visiting a Rosneft refinery on the Black Sea in 2013. Two years earlier, Exxon Mobil and Rosneft, a state-run oil company, had agreed on a $3.2 billion joint exploration pact.
item.description: A deepwater exploration agreement with the state-run oil company Rosneft was once one of Exxon’s most promising agreements.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: As Elections Near, Egypt Finds a New Target: Foreign News Media
item.media:description: Egypt has escalated attacks on civil liberties before a presidential election, even though President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi faces no real opposition.
item.description: Egypt’s prosecutor, blaming the “forces of evil” for negative coverage, warned of legal action against news outlets on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: U.S. Banks on Diplomacy With North Korea, but Moves Ahead on Military Plans
item.media:description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., middle left, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Gen. Mark A. Milley, middle right, the Army’s chief of staff, at the Capitol in January. General Milley helped run a planning exercise for a war with North Korea last week, and General Dunford has argued forcefully for using diplomacy to address Pyongyang’s nuclear program.
item.description: The American military is looking at everything from troop rotations to surveillance to casualty evacuations should it be ordered to take action against North Korea.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Letter 47: Poking and Prodding Democracy
item.description: This week’s Australia Letter highlights coverage and events exploring the state of democracy and gender. Plus, stories that make us smile.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Gun Control, Florida, Hope Hicks: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: The Interpreter: Lies, Damned Lies, and One Very Misleading Statistic
item.media:description: The rubble of Port-au-Prince after an earthquake struck Haiti in 2010. Some Oxfam workers there were reported to have paid survivors for sex.
item.description: An expert “estimate” that United Nations personnel sexually abused 60,000 people turns out to be more of a guess.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Trains Collide in Egypt, Killing at Least 12
item.media:description: Wreckage from the collision in the Nile Delta north of Cairo. Dozens were injured.
item.description: Rail accidents have killed hundreds in recent years in Egypt, a product of poor management and maintenance of the nation’s rail system.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Trump’s Nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize Was Apparently Forged. Twice.
item.media:description: Olav Njolstad, the secretary of the five-member Norwegian Nobel Committee, said Wednesday that a nomination of President Trump appeared to be a fake.
item.description: The police in Oslo said they were in contact with the F.B.I. about the forgeries, which suggests that they originated in the United States.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Why Can’t U.K. Solve the Irish Border Problem in Brexit?
item.media:description: A clothing shop in Muff, Ireland, near the border with Northern Ireland.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A plan by the European Union to avoid a hard border in Ireland provoked anger in Britain. Europeans say they still await British solutions.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Hungary’s Soros-Backed University Is Reaccredited
item.media:description: The Central European University in Budapest has been the subject of an intense battle in Hungary.
item.description: The Central European University in Budapest became a target last year in the government’s broader campaign against the financier.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Murdered Slovak Reporter Sought to Expose Italian Organized Crime
item.media:description: A vigil for the Slovak journalist Jan Kuciak and his fiancée, Martina Kusnirova, in Bratislava on Monday.
item.description: Colleagues of Jan Kuciak published an article he was working on when he and his fiancée were killed, including a look into an aide to Slovakia’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: In Peace Overture, Afghan President Offers Passports to Taliban
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan in Kabul on Wednesday. “We believe in providing a peaceful and respectful life for all Afghans, including those Taliban who leave violence behind,” he said.
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani offered to treat the insurgents as a legitimate political party if they join peace talks. The group has spurned similar offers in the past.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: An Arctic Storm Blows Into Britain
item.description: The weather front traveled across Europe from Siberia, bringing snow, ice, transportation gridlock and, for some, joy.

item.title: Tech We’re Using: Mexico Has Its Spyware. A Reporter Has a Few Phones to Juggle.
item.media:description: Azam Ahmed, the chief of The New York Times’s Mexico bureau, talking with an editor on a satellite phone while reporting from a remote Haitian village after Hurricane Matthew in 2016.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Our Mexico bureau chief, Azam Ahmed, uses various strategies to keep communications safe while reporting, including the low-tech tactic of in-person meetings.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Snowstorm Called ‘Beast From the East’ Sends Britons Scrambling
item.media:description: “Nothing works when it snows in England,” one commuter said. Central London was covered in snow as temperatures plunged below freezing on Wednesday after an Arctic storm blew in.
item.description: The storm shut schools, stranded drivers and disrupted trains and flights. But others said, “These Brits are so dramatic.”
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: 6 Aid Workers Killed Amid Chaos in Central African Republic
item.description: In a very poor nation racked by violence, Unicef said the victims were on their way to create a training program for teachers.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Bill Banning Circumcision in Iceland Alarms Religious Groups
item.media:description: Midday prayers at the Reykjavík Mosque in Iceland. Muslims in Iceland are concerned about a proposed ban on circumcision punishable by up to six years in prison.
item.description: Doctors, nurses and midwives have thrown their support behind the bill, which would ban circumcisions in children without a medical reason.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Dutch Supermarket Introduces Plastic-Free Aisle
item.media:description: Garbage including plastic bags in Nairobi, Kenya. Scientists estimate that 8.3 billion metric tons of plastic has been produced worldwide since the 1950s, with about 6.3 billion metric tons of that thrown away.
item.description: The initiative, part of a global push to fight waste, saw about 700 products packaged in compostable materials or in glass, metal or cardboard.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: In Taiwan, Young Protesters and Ex-Presidents Chafe Against China
item.media:description: Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei, Taiwan. While Chiang is still revered as a strong leader by some older residents, many younger Taiwanese oppose the use of his likeness or name in public spaces.
item.description: In very different ways on Wednesday, Taiwan citizens used a public holiday to call for the island’s 23 million people to have a greater say in their political identity.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: Blue Mountains Journal: How Immigrants Become Truly Canadian: On the Ski Slopes
item.media:description: Mahendran Arumugam, left, was one of many novice skiers at Blue Mountain resort on a recent Saturday.
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.description: Eager to embrace the Canadian way of life, a growing number of newcomers are hazarding a go at their adopted nation’s quintessential winter pastime.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Amid Turkish Assault, Kurdish Forces Are Drawn Away From U.S. Fight With ISIS
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. Jamie Jarrard, left, of the United States Army, with Muhammed Abu Adel, commander of the Manbij Military Council, in northern Syria earlier this month. Mr. Adel’s militia is among the Kurdish forces that have been key allies of the United States in the fight against the Islamic State in Syria.
item.description: Kurdish fighters in Syria who have been key in the American-led campaign against the Islamic State are peeling off to respond to Turkish attacks.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Interpreter: Xi Sets China on a Collision Course With History
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, front row center, at the closing ceremony of the Party Congress in Beijing last year.
item.description: China kept a half-century of global democratic growth at bay by at least nodding to the importance of institutions and rules. Now what?
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: The Interpreter: Episode 2: National Identity Is Made Up
item.description: Why do we identify with millions of strangers, just based on borders? In this video from The Interpreter, we explain the myth that built the modern world.
